tit.e: kirikane (a traditional technique of generating gold, silver or platinum patterns)
Kirikane (a traditional decorative technique by cut gold)
tit.cmt: 文頭を大文字にし、補足を変えました。
tit.e: Kirikane (a traditional decorative technique by cut gold)

sen.j: 截金・切金（きりかね）は、細金（ほそがね）とも呼ばれ、金箔・銀箔・プラチナ箔を数枚焼き合わせ、細い直線状に切ったり、三角形・菱形・丸型などの形に切った截箔（きりはく）を組み合わせ、筆と接着剤を用いて貼ることによって文様を表現する伝統技法である。
sen.e: kirikane (literally, cut leaf), also called hosogane (literally thinly cut leaf), indicates a traditional technique of generating gold, silver or platinum patterns in the following way: Several pieces of gold, silver or platinum leaf are burnt to be stuck together, the resultant leaf is cut into narrow long stripes, triangular shapes, diamond shapes or round shapes, and these cut pieces of leaf are combined and pasted with a brush and an adhesive to generate a pattern.

Kirikane (literally, cut leaf), which is also called hosogane (literally thinly cut leaf), refers to a traditional technique of creating patterns by using brushes to bond several leaves of gold, silver or platinum together, which are then burnt together and cut into shapes such as narrow rectangles, triangles, diamonds, or circles.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせて訳文を修正
sen.e: Kirikane (literally, cut leaf), which is also called hosogane (literally thinly cut leaf), refers to a traditional technique of creating patterns by using brushes to bond several leaves of gold, silver or platinum together, which are then burnt together and cut into shapes such as narrow rectangles, triangles, diamonds, or circles.

sen.j: 伝統的には仏像・仏画の衣や装身具を荘厳するために発達してきた。
sen.e: Traditionally, this technique was developed to make robes and accessories on Buddha statues or Buddhist paintings look stately.
Traditionally, this technique was developed to make robes and accessories on Buddha statues or Buddhist paintings look stately.
Traditionally, this technique was developed to make robes and accessories on Buddha statues or Buddhist paintings look stately.

sen.j: 現代では工芸として利用されることも多い。
sen.e: Nowadays, this technique is used in many craftworks as well.
Nowadays, this technique is used in many craftworks as well.
Nowadays, this technique is used in many craftworks as well.

sen.j: 海外の例として紀元前300-250年頃の「金箔入りガラス碗（サンドイッチ・グラス）」（大英博物館蔵、アレクサンドリア出土）があり、截金による植物文様を二層の透明ガラスの間に挟み込んだ作品がある。
sen.e: Overseas, a plant pattern generated using the kirikane technique is provided between two pieces of transparent glass in "A glass with gold leaf (sandwich glass)," which is considered generated around 300 to 250 BC (unearthed in Alexandria and owned by British Museum).

In other countries, 'Glass bowl with gold leaf' (Sandwich glass, unearthed in Alexandria and owned by the British Museum) around 300 to 250 BC has a plant pattern with the kirikane technique placed between the two layers of transparent glass.

In other countries, 'Glass bowl with gold leaf' (Sandwich glass, unearthed in Alexandria and owned by the British Museum) around 300 to 250 BC has a plant pattern with the kirikane technique placed between the two layers of transparent glass.

sen.j: 中国では北斉時代（550-577）の菩薩像２体（山東省・青州博物館蔵）に截金が見られ、一方は二重の亀甲文の中に亀を描いたものと、裳裾に縦長の亀甲文の中に３枚の葉をもった植物文を上下に重ねた文様に、もう一方は裳に緑と赤に白い丸文を描いた文様の区画の境界線に截金が使われている。
sen.e: In China, the kirikane technique was used on two statues of Bosatsu (bodhisattva) in Northern Qi period (550 - 577) (which are owned by Qingzhou Museum in Shandong Province) as in the following: In one of them, the technique was used for the tortoise drawn within a double-line kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) and for the pattern in which two plant patterns, each with three leaves, were drawn overlapped vertically, and in the other, the kirikane technique was used for the boundary line between a pattern where a white circle was drawn on a green portion in the area near to the hem and a pattern where a while circle was also drawn on a red part of the same area.

In China, the kirikane technique is found in two statues of Bosatsu (bodhisattva) in Northern Qi period (550 to 577) (owned by Qingzhou Museum in Shandong Province): For one of them, it is used in the motif of a double-line kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) in which a tortoise is drawn, and the motif which two patterns of plant with three leaves are arranged one above the other in a vertically long kikkomon in its mosuso (hem of pants), and for the other, in the boundary line between green pattern with white circle and red pattern with white circle in its mo (long pleated skirts).

In China, the kirikane technique is found in two statues of Bosatsu (bodhisattva) in Northern Qi period (550 to 577) (owned by Qingzhou Museum in Shandong Province): For one of them, it is used in the motif of a double-line kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) in which a tortoise is drawn, and the motif which two patterns of plant with three leaves are arranged one above the other in a vertically long kikkomon in its mosuso (hem of pants), and for the other, in the boundary line between green pattern with white circle and red pattern with white circle in its mo (long pleated skirts).

sen.j: 朝鮮半島では6世紀前半、百済の忠清南道武寧王陵出土の王妃木製頭枕に朱漆と思われる赤色に着色された表面に、幅をもたせて帯のように切られた線状の金箔による亀甲文様が施されているのが確認されている。
sen.e: In the Korean peninsular, use of thin belt-like straight gold leaf for the kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) was confirmed on the red-colored (presumably, red-lacquered) surface of the wooden support for a princess's head that was unearthed from the tomb of King Muryeong in Sud Chungcheong in Baekje, considered built in the first half of the six century.

In the Korean peninsular, thin belt-like straight gold leaf for the kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) is confirmed on the red-colored (presumably, red-lacquered) surface of the wooden pillow for a princess unearthed from the tomb of King Muryeong in Sud Chungcheong in Baekje, in the early sixth century.

In the Korean peninsular, thin belt-like straight gold leaf for the kikkomon (hexagonal pattern) is confirmed on the red-colored (presumably, red-lacquered) surface of the wooden pillow for a princess unearthed from the tomb of King Muryeong in Sud Chungcheong in Baekje, in the early sixth century.

sen.j: 日本においては7世紀半ばの飛鳥時代に朝鮮半島や中国大陸より仏像彫刻や仏画とともに伝わったといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that the technique was brought to Japan in the Asuka period (from around the end of sixth century to the early eight century) together with Buddhist sculptures and Buddhist paintings from the Korean peninsular and continental China.

It is said that the technique was brought to Japan in the Asuka period, in the midst seventh century, together with Buddhist sculptures and Buddhist paintings from the Korean peninsular and continental China.

It is said that the technique was brought to Japan in the Asuka period, in the midst seventh century, together with Buddhist sculptures and Buddhist paintings from the Korean peninsular and continental China.

sen.j: 法隆寺所蔵玉虫厨子の須弥座上框下の請花花弁先端部分に小さな長菱形の金箔が施されており、これが国内に現存する最古の截金作品とされる。
sen.e: A tiny piece of long lozenge-shaped gold leaf is used at the tips of petals of ukebana (a flower-like accessory) under the agarigamachi (the horizontal bar at the entrance) of shumiza (dais for a Buddhist image) of Tamamushi-no-Zushi (literally, Beetle Shrine) owned by Horyu-ji Temple, and it is said that this is the oldest remaining kirikane-using product in Japan.

A tiny long lozenge-shaped gold leaf is used at the tips of petals of ukebana (a flower-like accessory) under the agarigamachi (the horizontal bar at the entrance) of shumiza (dais for a Buddhist statue) of Tamamushi-no-Zushi (literally, Beetle Shrine) owned by Horyu-ji Temple, which is considered as the oldest remaining kirikane-using product in Japan.

A tiny long lozenge-shaped gold leaf is used at the tips of petals of ukebana (a flower-like accessory) under the agarigamachi (the horizontal bar at the entrance) of shumiza (dais for a Buddhist statue) of Tamamushi-no-Zushi (literally, Beetle Shrine) owned by Horyu-ji Temple, which is considered as the oldest remaining kirikane-using product in Japan.

sen.j: 奈良時代には東大寺法華堂（三月堂）の乾漆造四天王立像（国宝）の仏像の衣や甲冑の装飾、東大寺戒壇堂の塑造四天王像の着衣の地文に直線文と点綴文の截金が使用されている。
sen.e: In the Nara period, the kirikane technique was used for the decorations of the robes and Kacchu (armors and helmets) of the kanshitsu-shitenno ryuzo (dry lacquer standing statues of the four guardian kings), (national treasure) Buddha statues in Hokke-do Hall (Sangatsu-do) of Todai-ji Temple.

In the Nara period, the kirikane technique in straight-line or was used for the decorations of the robes and Katchu (armors and helmets) of the Kanshitsu Shitenno ryuzo (dry lacquer standing statues of the four guardian kings) (national treasure) in Hokke-do Hall (also referred as Sangatsu-do) of Todai-ji Temple, and for the clothes' base pattern of Sozo Shitenno zo (molding statue of the four guardian kings) in Kaidan-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple.

In the Nara period, the kirikane technique in straight-line or was used for the decorations of the robes and Katchu (armors and helmets) of the Kanshitsu Shitenno ryuzo (dry lacquer standing statues of the four guardian kings) (national treasure) in Hokke-do Hall (also referred as Sangatsu-do) of Todai-ji Temple, and for the clothes' base pattern of Sozo Shitenno zo (molding statue of the four guardian kings) in Kaidan-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 正倉院正倉院宝物の新羅琴・金薄輪草形鳳形（しらぎごと・きんぱくわのくさがたおおとりがた）には菱、松葉、草花文や曲線で表現した鳳凰文などの截金文様を見ることができる。
sen.e: On the Shiragi-goto (Shiragi-style koto) called Kimpaku wanokusagata otorigata (literally, grass and big bird patterns using thin gold rings) in the Shoso-in treasures, patterns using the kirikane techniques, such as lozenges, pine leaves, grass flowers and a phoenix drawn using curves, can be seen.

On the Shiragi-goto (Shiragi-style koto) called Kinpaku wanokusagata otorigata (literally, grass and big bird patterns using thin gold rings) in the Shosoin Treasures, patterns with the kirikane techniques, such as lozenges, pine leaves, grass flowers and a phoenix drawn using curves, and so on, can be seen.

On the Shiragi-goto (Shiragi-style koto) called Kinpaku wanokusagata otorigata (literally, grass and big bird patterns using thin gold rings) in the Shosoin Treasures, patterns with the kirikane techniques, such as lozenges, pine leaves, grass flowers and a phoenix drawn using curves, and so on, can be seen.

sen.j: 平安時代には仏画の荘厳に截金が取り入れられた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the kirikane technique was introduced for giving the stateliness to Buddhist paintings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Heian period, the kirikane technique was introduced for giving the stateliness to Buddhist paintings.
In the Heian period, the kirikane technique was introduced for giving the stateliness to Buddhist paintings.

sen.j: 平安時代後期の高野山金剛峰寺の仏涅槃図や東京国立博物館蔵の金棺出現図などの仏画に繊細な截金文様を駆使したものがある。
sen.e: For example, on the Butsu Nehan-zu (painting of Buddha nirvana) of Koyasan Kongobu-ji Temple (Kongobu-ji Temple in Mt. koya), which was drawn in the latter half of the Heian period, and on Kinkan Shutsugenzu (Rising from the Gold Coffin), which is owned by Tokyo National Museum, delicate patterns are drawn using the kirikane technique deftly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, on the Butsu Nehan-zu (painting of Buddha nirvana) of Kongobu-ji Temple in Mt. Koya in the late Heian period, and on Kinkan Shutsugenzu (Rising from the Gold Coffin) owned by Tokyo National Museum, delicate patterns are drawn using the kirikane technique deftly.

For example, on the Butsu Nehan-zu (painting of Buddha nirvana) of Kongobu-ji Temple in Mt. Koya in the late Heian period, and on Kinkan Shutsugenzu (Rising from the Gold Coffin) owned by Tokyo National Museum, delicate patterns are drawn using the kirikane technique deftly.

sen.j: これらの例から、仏教美術の隆盛と共に截金は飛躍的な発展を遂げたことが窺える。
sen.e: From these examples, it is known that the kirikane technique had developed dramatically corresponding to the prosperity of Buddhist art.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From these examples, it is known that the kirikane technique had developed dramatically corresponding to the prosperity of Buddhist art.
From these examples, it is known that the kirikane technique had developed dramatically corresponding to the prosperity of Buddhist art.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には仏師快慶の活躍により新しい文様が生まれた。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, new patterns were created by efforts of Kaikei, a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, new patterns were created by efforts of Kaikei, a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues).
In the Kamakura period, new patterns were created by efforts of Kaikei, a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues).

sen.j: しかしながら、室町時代から江戸時代にかけては次第に形式化し、また金箔に代わり金泥による文様も普及した。
sen.e: However, in the era from the Muromach period to the Edo period, the patterns became fixed gradually, and in addition, patterns using kindei (gold paint), instead of kirikane, had become used widely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, from the Muromachi period to the Edo period, the patterns became fixed gradually, and in addition, patterns using kindei (gold paint), instead of kirikane, had become used widely.
However, from the Muromachi period to the Edo period, the patterns became fixed gradually, and in addition, patterns using kindei (gold paint), instead of kirikane, had become used widely.

sen.j: そのため、それ以降は継承者が少なくなっていった。
sen.e: Therefore, after then, the number of persons inheriting the technique diminished gradually.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, after then, the number of persons inheriting the technique diminished gradually.
Therefore, after then, the number of persons inheriting the technique diminished gradually.

sen.j: 近世以降は東西両本願寺の庇護のもとで限られた人にのみ伝承される技になってしまった。
sen.e: In the early-modern times and later, kirikane became a technique that was inherited among a limited number of persons under the support of Higashi (eastern) Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi (western) Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the early-modern times and later, kirikane became a technique that was inherited among a limited number of persons under the support of Higashi (eastern) Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi (western) Hongan-ji Temple.

In the early-modern times and later, kirikane became a technique that was inherited among a limited number of persons under the support of Higashi (eastern) Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi (western) Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: しかしながら、現代になりその技法を伝えようとする人々が現れ、徐々にではあるが認知されつつある。
sen.e: However, the persons making efforts to hand the technique down to later generations have appeared recently, and its value has been becoming recognized, though little by little.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the persons making efforts to hand the technique down to later generations have appeared recently, and its value has been becoming recognized, though little by little.
However, the persons making efforts to hand the technique down to later generations have appeared recently, and its value has been becoming recognized, though little by little.

sen.j: 今後は日本において截金の技術をどのように継承発展させていくかが大きな課題である。
sen.e: Hereafter, how to inherit and develop the kirikane technique in Japan is a big problem.
Hereafter, how to inherit and develop the kirikane technique in Japan is a big problem.

sen.j: 金箔
sen.e: Gold leaf
Gold leaf
Gold leaf

sen.j: 金を1万分の4-7 ミリメートルまで薄く延ばしたもので、通常大きさが3寸6分角（約11平方メートル）の箔が用いられる。
sen.e: A piece of gold leaf that is used ordinarily is made as thin as 4/10,000 to 7/10,000 millimeters and its size is approx. 11 square meters.
sen.cmt: 約11平方メートル： ”約11センチメートル平方”の誤りかも知れないという気がしましたが、原文どおりに訳してあります。
sen.e: A gold leaf from 4/10,000 to 7/10,000 millimeters thick, approximately 11 centimeters square is usually used.
sen.cmt: 主文の3寸6分は約11cmなので、11cmと表記しました。

sen.j: これを2枚焼き合わせ、さらに両面に1枚ずつ焼き合わせる。
sen.e: Two of these pieces are burnt to be stuck, and then another piece is burnt to be stuck to each side of the resultant gold leaf.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Two sheets of them are burnt together, then another sheet is done in its both faces.
Two sheets of them are burnt together, then another sheet is done in its both faces.

sen.j: この処理を繰り返し4～6枚ほどの厚みにしてから使用する。
sen.e: The above process is repeated until the thickness becomes four to six times that of the original piece of gold leaf.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is used after the above process which is repeated several times until four to six sheets are burnt together.
It is used after the above process which is repeated several times until four to six sheets are burnt together.

sen.j: 縁付（えんつき・えんづけ）と断切（たちきり）の2種類販売されている。
sen.e: Two types of gold leaf, called entsuki or enzuke and tachikiri, are sold.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Two types of gold leaf, called entsuki (leaf which is cut individually and sandwiched between sheets of specially made paper, also referred as enzuke) and tachikiri (leaf which is cut all together after being put between sheets of paper to make stacks of over 1000) are sold.

Two types of gold leaf, called entsuki (leaf which is cut individually and sandwiched between sheets of specially made paper, also referred as enzuke) and tachikiri (leaf which is cut all together after being put between sheets of paper to make stacks of over 1000) are sold.

sen.j: しかしながら、断切は硬く扱いにくいため縁付が好んで使用される。
sen.e: However, because the tachikiri type is hard and cannot be handled easily, the entsuki type is used preferably.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, because the tachikiri type is hard and cannot be handled easily, the entsuki type is used preferably.

sen.j: 湿気を嫌うので焼き合わせは好天の日を選び、雨の日や梅雨時は避けたほうがよい。
sen.e: Because humidity should be avoided for this material, the burning operation to make pieces of gold leaf stuck should be performed on fine days, avoiding rainy days and the rainy season.
Because humidity should be avoided for this material, the burning operation to make pieces of gold leaf stuck should be performed on fine days, avoiding rainy days and the rainy season.

sen.e: In addition to the main image where the main face, a Buddha face at the top, eleven small-sized faces and 21 big arms are depicted, Kudokuten (the goddess of fortune and merit) is painted on one side of the main image and Basusen on the other side.

In addition to the main face and the Buddha face at the top, the image has 11 small-sized faces and each 21 big arms in right and left respectively, and Kudokuten (the goddess of fortune and merit) is painted on one side of the main image and Basusen (Buddhist hermit who continually goes on pilgrimage through the wilderness, saving beings who have lost their way) on the other side.

This depicts Ichiji Kinrin (also referred as Dainichi Kinrin) seating in a typical Buddhist style with Nichirin (the sun) on the back at the center on Mt. Sumeru, whose clothes provide delicate kirikane patterns of connected shippo, tachiwaku and ishidatami (checker) and others.

This depicts Ichiji Kinrin (also referred as Dainichi Kinrin) seating in a typical Buddhist style with Nichirin (the sun) on the back at the center on Mt. Sumeru, whose clothes provide delicate kirikane patterns of connected shippo, tachiwaku and ishidatami (checker) and others.
